#### 1.7 Page: Exams

Exams are an essential component of this course and are designed to assess students' understanding of the course material. They will be held at regular intervals throughout the semester and will cover a range of topics, from problem-solving to critical thinking.

##### 1.7a Introduction to Exams

Exams will be held at specific dates and times, as outlined in the course schedule. They will be comprehensive assessments of students' knowledge and skills, and will be weighted heavily in the final grade.

Exams will be graded based on their completeness and accuracy. It is important for students to prepare thoroughly for each exam and to make every effort to ensure their accuracy. Late exams will not be accepted unless there is a valid excuse.

##### 1.7b Types of Exams

There will be three types of exams in this course: midterms, finals, and take-home exams.

Midterms will be held at the midpoint of the semester and will cover the material taught up to that point. They will be comprehensive assessments of students' knowledge and skills, and will be weighted heavily in the final grade.

Finals will be held at the end of the semester and will cover the entire course material. They will be comprehensive assessments of students' knowledge and skills, and will be weighted heavily in the final grade.

Take-home exams will be completed by students on their own time. These exams will be more complex and will require students to apply their knowledge to a real-world scenario. They will also give students the opportunity to explore the course material in more depth.

##### 1.7c Preparing for Exams

Students are encouraged to prepare for exams by reviewing their notes, completing practice problems, and studying with their peers. The course website will also provide sample exams and practice questions to help students prepare.

In addition, students are encouraged to attend review sessions and study groups, which will be organized by the course staff. These sessions will provide additional opportunities for students to review the course material and to ask questions.

Finally, students are encouraged to take care of their physical and mental health during the exam period. This includes getting enough sleep, eating well, and managing stress. The MIT Student Support Services can provide additional resources and support for students who need it.

##### 1.7b Types of Exams (Continued)

Midterms will be held at the midpoint of the semester and will cover the material taught up to that point. They will be comprehensive assessments of students' knowledge and skills, and will be weighted heavily in the final grade.

Finals will be held at the end of the semester and will cover the entire course material. They will be comprehensive assessments of students' knowledge and skills, and will be weighted heavily in the final grade.

Take-home exams will be completed by students on their own time. These exams will be more complex and will require students to apply their knowledge to a real-world scenario. They will also give students the opportunity to explore the course material in more depth.

##### 1.7c Preparing for Exams

Preparing for exams is a crucial part of success in this course. Here are some strategies to help you prepare:

1. Review your notes regularly. Make sure you understand the key concepts and can apply them to solve problems.

2. Practice, practice, practice. The best way to prepare for exams is to practice solving problems. Use the practice problems provided in the textbook and on the course website.

3. Study with your peers. Forming a study group with your classmates can be a great way to prepare for exams. You can discuss concepts, solve problems together, and learn from each other.

4. Attend review sessions. The course staff will organize review sessions before each exam. These sessions will provide an opportunity to review the material and ask any questions you may have.

5. Take care of your physical and mental health. Make sure you are getting enough sleep, eating well, and managing your stress. These factors can have a significant impact on your performance on exams.

6. Use the resources provided. The course website will provide sample exams and practice questions to help you prepare. Make sure you take advantage of these resources.

Remember, the goal of exams is not just to test your knowledge, but also to help you learn. By preparing thoroughly for exams, you can not only do well on the exams themselves, but also deepen your understanding of the course material.

#### 1.7d Review of Exams

After each exam, it is crucial to take some time to review your performance. This process will not only help you understand your strengths and weaknesses, but also provide valuable insights into your learning process. Here are some steps to guide you through the review process:

1. **Review your exam paper**: Go through each question and try to understand why you got it right or wrong. If you got a question wrong, try to understand the conceptual error you made. This will help you avoid similar mistakes in the future.

2. **Reflect on your preparation**: Think about how you prepared for the exam. What strategies worked well? What didn't? This reflection can help you improve your study habits and exam preparation for future exams.

3. **Discuss with your peers**: Talking to your peers about the exam can be a great way to learn. You can share insights, discuss difficult questions, and learn from each other's experiences.

4. **Seek feedback from the course staff**: Don't hesitate to reach out to the course staff if you have any questions or concerns about your exam performance. They are there to help you succeed.

5. **Plan for improvement**: Based on your review and reflection, make a plan for how you will improve your performance in future exams. This could involve spending more time on certain topics, changing your study habits, or seeking additional help.

Remember, the goal of exams is not just to test your knowledge, but also to help you learn. By taking the time to review your exams, you can make the most of this learning opportunity.

## Chapter: Chapter 2: Nonlinear Planning Models

### Introduction

In the realm of planning and decision-making, the linear approach has been the traditional norm. However, the complexity of real-world problems often necessitates a departure from linearity, leading to the need for nonlinear planning models. This chapter, "Nonlinear Planning Models," delves into the intricacies of these models, their applications, and the unique challenges they present.

Nonlinear planning models are mathematical representations of complex systems that do not adhere to the principles of linearity. They are used to model and solve problems where the output is not directly proportional to the input, or where the relationship between cause and effect is not linear. These models are particularly useful in situations where the system under study exhibits nonlinear behavior, such as in economics, engineering, and environmental science.

The chapter will explore the fundamental concepts of nonlinear planning models, including the principles of nonlinearity, the role of nonlinear functions, and the techniques used to solve these models. It will also discuss the advantages and limitations of nonlinear planning models, and how they compare to linear models.

The chapter will also delve into the practical aspects of nonlinear planning models, providing examples of their application in various fields. It will discuss how these models can be used to solve real-world problems, and how they can help decision-makers make more informed choices.

Finally, the chapter will address the challenges associated with nonlinear planning models, including the difficulties of model validation and the need for computational resources. It will also discuss strategies for overcoming these challenges, and for making the most of the opportunities presented by nonlinear planning models.

In essence, this chapter aims to provide a comprehensive guide to nonlinear planning models, equipping readers with the knowledge and skills they need to apply these models in their own work. Whether you are a student, a researcher, or a professional, this chapter will serve as a valuable resource in your journey towards mastering the art of nonlinear planning.

##### 1.8b Course Description

Risk Aware and Robust Nonlinear Planning is an advanced undergraduate course at MIT that focuses on the application of nonlinear planning techniques to complex systems. The course is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the principles and methods of nonlinear planning, and to equip them with the skills to apply these techniques to real-world problems.

The course is divided into three main parts. The first part introduces the concept of nonlinear planning and its importance in complex systems. The second part delves into the principles and methods of nonlinear planning, including sensitivity analysis, robust optimization, and feedback control. The third part applies these principles and methods to a range of real-world problems, including engineering design, supply chain management, and financial planning.

Throughout the course, students will be exposed to a variety of mathematical and computational techniques, including differential equations, optimization theory, and simulation methods. They will also learn how to use software tools for nonlinear planning, such as MATLAB and Simulink.

By the end of this course, students will have a solid understanding of nonlinear planning and its applications, and will be able to apply these techniques to solve complex problems in a variety of fields.

##### 1.8c Course Objectives

The primary objectives of this course are as follows:

1. To provide students with a comprehensive understanding of nonlinear planning and its importance in complex systems.

2. To equip students with the skills to apply nonlinear planning techniques to real-world problems.

3. To introduce students to a variety of mathematical and computational techniques, including differential equations, optimization theory, and simulation methods.

4. To familiarize students with software tools for nonlinear planning, such as MATLAB and Simulink.

5. To develop students' ability to think critically and creatively about complex systems and their planning challenges.

6. To foster students' ability to work collaboratively and communicate effectively in a team setting.

7. To encourage students to engage in independent learning and research, and to develop their own ideas and approaches to nonlinear planning.

## Chapter: Risk Aware and Robust Nonlinear Planning: A Comprehensive Guide

### Introduction

In today's complex and uncertain world, planning for the future is becoming increasingly challenging. Traditional linear planning methods, which assume a linear relationship between inputs and outputs, are often insufficient to handle the nonlinearities and uncertainties that exist in real-world systems. This is where risk aware and robust nonlinear planning comes into play.

In this chapter, we will explore the concept of risk aware and robust nonlinear planning, and how it can be applied to various fields such as engineering, economics, and finance. We will begin by discussing the limitations of traditional linear planning methods and how they can lead to suboptimal solutions. We will then delve into the fundamentals of nonlinear planning, including the use of mathematical models and optimization techniques to handle nonlinearities and uncertainties.

Next, we will introduce the concept of risk awareness in planning, and how it can be used to account for potential risks and uncertainties in the future. We will discuss various risk assessment and management techniques, and how they can be integrated into the planning process. We will also explore the concept of robust planning, which involves designing systems that are resilient to unexpected changes and disruptions.

Finally, we will provide practical examples and case studies to demonstrate the application of risk aware and robust nonlinear planning in real-world scenarios. By the end of this chapter, readers will have a comprehensive understanding of the principles and techniques involved in risk aware and robust nonlinear planning, and how they can be applied to their own planning processes.

## Chapter 2: Overview of Nonlinear Optimization:

### Introduction

Nonlinear optimization is a powerful tool that allows us to find the optimal solution to a problem with nonlinear constraints. In this chapter, we will provide an overview of nonlinear optimization, discussing its importance and applications in various fields. We will also introduce the concept of risk awareness and robustness in nonlinear optimization, and how it can be used to handle uncertainties and risks in the optimization process.

Nonlinear optimization is a branch of optimization that deals with finding the optimal solution to a problem with nonlinear constraints. Unlike linear optimization, where the constraints are linear functions, nonlinear optimization deals with constraints that are nonlinear functions. This makes the optimization problem more complex and challenging, but also more realistic and applicable to real-world problems.

One of the key challenges in nonlinear optimization is the presence of multiple local optima. Unlike linear optimization, where the optimal solution is unique, nonlinear optimization can have multiple local optima, making it difficult to determine the global optimal solution. This is where risk awareness and robustness come into play. By incorporating risk awareness and robustness into the optimization process, we can handle uncertainties and risks in the problem, and find a solution that is not only optimal, but also robust and reliable.

In this chapter, we will also discuss the different types of nonlinear optimization problems, such as unconstrained and constrained optimization, and the various techniques used to solve them. We will also touch upon the concept of convexity and its importance in nonlinear optimization. Additionally, we will explore the role of sensitivity analysis in nonlinear optimization, and how it can be used to understand the behavior of the optimal solution.

Overall, this chapter aims to provide a comprehensive overview of nonlinear optimization, setting the foundation for the rest of the book. By the end of this chapter, readers will have a better understanding of the fundamentals of nonlinear optimization and its applications, and will be ready to delve deeper into the more advanced topics covered in the subsequent chapters. 


## Chapter 2: Overview of Nonlinear Optimization:




### Subsection: 2.1 Optimality Conditions

In the previous section, we discussed the importance of optimality conditions in nonlinear optimization. In this section, we will delve deeper into the concept of optimality conditions and discuss the necessary conditions for optimality.

#### Necessary Conditions for Optimality

The necessary conditions for optimality are a set of conditions that must be satisfied by the optimal solution of a nonlinear optimization problem. These conditions are derived from the first-order optimality conditions, which state that at the optimal solution, the gradient of the objective function must be equal to the gradient of the Lagrangian.

The necessary conditions for optimality can be summarized as follows:

1. Stationarity: The gradient of the objective function must be equal to the gradient of the Lagrangian at the optimal solution. This means that the optimal solution must satisfy the first-order optimality conditions.
2. Convexity: The objective function must be convex and the constraints must be convex and differentiable. This ensures that the optimization problem has a unique optimal solution.
3. Slater's condition: This condition states that the objective function must be strictly convex and the constraints must be strictly convex and differentiable. This ensures that the optimization problem has a unique optimal solution.
4. Second-order sufficient conditions: These conditions involve the second derivatives of the objective function and the constraints. They are used to verify the optimality of the solution.

#### Sufficient Conditions for Optimality

In some cases, the necessary conditions are also sufficient for optimality. This means that if the necessary conditions are satisfied, then the solution is also optimal. The sufficient conditions for optimality can be summarized as follows:

1. Concavity of the objective function: If the objective function is a differentiable concave function, the inequality constraints are differentiable convex functions, and the equality constraints are affine functions, and Slater's condition holds, then the necessary conditions are sufficient for optimality.
2. Convexity of the objective function: If the objective function is a differentiable convex function, the necessary conditions are also sufficient for optimality.
3. Type 1 invexity: If the objective function is a Type 1 invex function, then the necessary conditions are sufficient for optimality.

#### Second-order Sufficient Conditions

For smooth, non-linear optimization problems, a second order sufficient condition is given as follows:

The solution $x^*, \lambda^*, \mu^*$ found in the above section is a constrained local minimum if for the Lagrangian,

$$
\nabla L(x^*,\lambda^*,\mu^*) = 0
$$

where $s \ne 0$ is a vector satisfying the following,

$$
s^T\nabla^2_{xx}L(x^*,\lambda^*,\mu^*)s = 0
$$

where only those active inequality constraints $g_i(x)$ corresponding to strict complementarity (i.e. where $\mu_i > 0$) are applied. The solution is a strict constrained local minimum in the case the inequality is also strict.

If $s^T\nabla^2_{xx}L(x^*,\lambda^*,\mu^*)s = 0$, the third order Taylor expansion of the Lagrangian should be used to verify if $x^*$ is a local minimum. The minimization of $f(x_1,x_2)=(x_2-x_1^2)(x_2-3x_1^2)$ is a good counter-example, see also Peano surface.

In the next section, we will discuss the different types of nonlinear optimization problems and the techniques used to solve them.


## Chapter 2: Overview of Nonlinear Optimization:




### Subsection: 2.2 Newton's Method

Newton's method is a popular optimization algorithm that is used to find the roots of a function. It is an iterative method that uses the first and second derivatives of the function to find the root. In this section, we will discuss the basics of Newton's method and its application in nonlinear optimization.

#### Introduction to Newton's Method

Newton's method is a root-finding algorithm that is used to find the roots of a function. It is an iterative method that uses the first and second derivatives of the function to find the root. The algorithm works by approximating the root of the function using the tangent line at a given point. The root is then approximated by the intersection of the tangent line and the x-axis.

The algorithm starts with an initial guess for the root, denoted by $x_0$. The first derivative of the function, denoted by $f'(x)$, is then evaluated at $x_0$. If $f'(x_0) \neq 0$, the algorithm terminates with the conclusion that the function has no root in the interval $[x_0, x_0 + h]$. If $f'(x_0) = 0$, the algorithm proceeds to the next step.

The second derivative of the function, denoted by $f''(x)$, is then evaluated at $x_0$. If $f''(x_0) \neq 0$, the algorithm uses the tangent line approximation to find the root. The root is then approximated by the intersection of the tangent line and the x-axis. The algorithm then iterates, using the new root as the initial guess for the next iteration.

#### Application in Nonlinear Optimization

Newton's method is also widely used in nonlinear optimization. In this context, the function being optimized is the objective function, and the constraints are represented as equality and inequality constraints. The algorithm works by finding the roots of the first and second derivatives of the objective function, which represent the gradient and Hessian matrix, respectively.

The algorithm starts with an initial guess for the optimal solution, denoted by $\boldsymbol{\beta}^{(0)}$. The first derivative of the objective function, denoted by $\mathbf{J_r}$, is then evaluated at $\boldsymbol{\beta}^{(0)}$. If $\mathbf{J_r} = 0$, the algorithm terminates with the conclusion that the objective function has no minimum in the given interval. If $\mathbf{J_r} \neq 0$, the algorithm proceeds to the next step.

The second derivative of the objective function, denoted by $\mathbf{J_r}^\mathsf{T} \mathbf{J_r}$, is then evaluated at $\boldsymbol{\beta}^{(0)}$. If $\mathbf{J_r}^\mathsf{T} \mathbf{J_r} \neq 0$, the algorithm uses the Jacobian matrix to find the minimum. The minimum is then approximated by the intersection of the Jacobian matrix and the null space of the constraints. The algorithm then iterates, using the new minimum as the initial guess for the next iteration.

#### Conclusion

In this section, we have discussed the basics of Newton's method and its application in nonlinear optimization. Newton's method is a powerful optimization algorithm that is widely used in various fields, including engineering, economics, and machine learning. Its ability to handle nonlinear functions and constraints makes it a valuable tool for solving complex optimization problems. In the next section, we will discuss another popular optimization algorithm, the Gauss-Seidel method, and its application in nonlinear optimization.





### Subsection: 2.3 Interior Point Method

The Interior Point Method (IPM) is a powerful optimization technique that has gained popularity in recent years due to its ability to handle nonlinear constraints and non-convex problems. It is based on the concept of barrier functions, which are used to encode the feasible set of a convex optimization problem.

#### Introduction to Interior Point Method

The Interior Point Method is a class of algorithms that solve linear and nonlinear convex optimization problems. It was first discovered by Soviet mathematician I. I. Dikin in 1967 and later reinvented in the U.S. in the mid-1980s. The method is also known as barrier methods or IPMs.

The basic idea behind the Interior Point Method is to reach a best solution by traversing the interior of the feasible region. This is in contrast to the simplex method, which reaches a best solution by moving along the edges of the feasible region. The Interior Point Method is particularly useful for problems with a large number of variables and constraints, as it can handle these problems more efficiently than the simplex method.

#### Karmarkar's Algorithm

One of the most notable applications of the Interior Point Method is Karmarkar's algorithm, developed by Narendra Karmarkar in 1984. This algorithm is used to solve linear programming problems and is particularly efficient for problems with a large number of variables and constraints. It runs in polynomial time and is also efficient in practice.

Karmarkar's algorithm is based on the concept of barrier functions, which are used to encode the feasible set of a convex optimization problem. These barrier functions are used to guide the algorithm towards a best solution by traversing the interior of the feasible region. The algorithm is also able to handle nonlinear constraints and non-convex problems, making it a powerful tool for solving a wide range of optimization problems.

#### Complexity of Interior Point Method

The complexity of the Interior Point Method depends on the size of the problem and the type of constraints. For linear programming problems with a large number of variables and constraints, the complexity is polynomial. However, for nonlinear and non-convex problems, the complexity can be exponential.

In conclusion, the Interior Point Method is a powerful optimization technique that has gained popularity in recent years due to its ability to handle nonlinear constraints and non-convex problems. It is particularly useful for problems with a large number of variables and constraints, and its complexity is polynomial for linear programming problems.

### Subsection: 2.4 Dual Optimization

Dual optimization is a powerful technique used in nonlinear optimization to solve problems with multiple variables and constraints. It is based on the concept of duality, which states that every optimization problem has a dual problem that is equivalent to it. The dual problem is a simplified version of the original problem that provides a lower bound on the optimal solution.

#### Introduction to Dual Optimization

Dual optimization is a method used to solve nonlinear optimization problems. It is based on the concept of duality, which states that every optimization problem has a dual problem that is equivalent to it. The dual problem is a simplified version of the original problem that provides a lower bound on the optimal solution.

The dual problem is formulated as:

$$
\min_{y} \max_{x} \mathbf{c}^T x - \mathbf{d}^T y
$$

subject to:

$$
\mathbf{A} x \leq \mathbf{b}
$$

$$
\mathbf{A}^T y \geq \mathbf{c}
$$

where $\mathbf{c}$ and $\mathbf{d}$ are the objective function coefficients, $\mathbf{A}$ is the constraint matrix, and $\mathbf{b}$ is the right-hand side vector.

The dual problem is a simplified version of the original problem, as it only involves minimizing and maximizing linear functions, rather than nonlinear functions. This makes it easier to solve, especially for large-scale problems.

#### Applications of Dual Optimization

Dual optimization has many applications in nonlinear optimization. One of the most notable applications is in the field of sparse dictionary learning. Sparse dictionary learning is a technique used to learn a dictionary of atoms that can represent a given set of data. The Lagrange dual method, which is based on solving a dual Lagrangian problem, provides an efficient way to solve for the dictionary.

Another application of dual optimization is in the field of least absolute shrinkage and selection operator (LASSO). LASSO is a technique used to solve linear regression problems with a large number of variables. It finds an estimate of the solution vector by minimizing the least square error subject to a "L"<sup>1</sup>-norm constraint. This is formulated as:

$$
\min_{r \in \mathbb{R}^n} \,\, \dfrac{1}{2}\,\,\|X-\mathbf{D}r\|^2_F + \lambda \,\,\|r\|_1
$$

where $\lambda > 0$ controls the trade-off between sparsity and the reconstruction error. This gives the global optimal solution.

#### Complexity of Dual Optimization

The complexity of dual optimization depends on the size and structure of the original problem. In general, the complexity is polynomial, making it a practical method for solving large-scale problems. However, the specific complexity depends on the problem instance and may be higher in some cases.

### Subsection: 2.5 Convex Optimization

Convex optimization is a powerful technique used in nonlinear optimization to solve problems with convex objective functions and convex constraints. It is based on the concept of convexity, which states that the sum of convex functions is convex. This property allows us to solve complex optimization problems by breaking them down into simpler convex subproblems.

#### Introduction to Convex Optimization

Convex optimization is a method used to solve nonlinear optimization problems with convex objective functions and convex constraints. It is based on the concept of convexity, which states that the sum of convex functions is convex. This property allows us to solve complex optimization problems by breaking them down into simpler convex subproblems.

The convex optimization problem is formulated as:

$$
\min_{x} f(x)
$$

subject to:

$$
g(x) \leq 0
$$

where $f(x)$ is the objective function and $g(x)$ is the constraint function. Both $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ are convex functions.

The convex optimization problem can be solved using various optimization algorithms, such as gradient descent, Newton's method, and the simplex method. These algorithms provide a way to find the optimal solution, which is the point that minimizes the objective function while satisfying all the constraints.

#### Applications of Convex Optimization

Convex optimization has many applications in various fields, including engineering, economics, and machine learning. In engineering, it is used to design optimal control systems, signal processing algorithms, and communication systems. In economics, it is used to solve portfolio optimization problems, production planning problems, and resource allocation problems. In machine learning, it is used to train neural networks, support vector machines, and other machine learning models.

One of the most notable applications of convex optimization is in the field of sparse dictionary learning. Sparse dictionary learning is a technique used to learn a dictionary of atoms that can represent a given set of data. The convex optimization formulation of this problem allows us to find the optimal dictionary efficiently and accurately.

Another important application of convex optimization is in the field of least absolute shrinkage and selection operator (LASSO). LASSO is a technique used to solve linear regression problems with a large number of variables. The convex optimization formulation of this problem allows us to find the optimal solution efficiently and accurately.

In conclusion, convex optimization is a powerful technique that has numerous applications in various fields. Its ability to break down complex optimization problems into simpler convex subproblems makes it a valuable tool for solving real-world problems.

### Subsection: 2.6 Linear Program

Linear programming is a powerful optimization technique used to solve problems with linear objective functions and linear constraints. It is a special case of convex optimization, where the objective function and constraints are all linear functions. Linear programming is widely used in various fields, including finance, engineering, and operations research.

#### Introduction to Linear Program

Linear programming is a method used to solve optimization problems with linear objective functions and linear constraints. It is based on the concept of linearity, which states that the sum of linear functions is linear. This property allows us to solve complex optimization problems by breaking them down into simpler linear subproblems.

The linear programming problem is formulated as:

$$
\min_{x} c^Tx
$$

subject to:

$$
Ax \leq b
$$

where $c$ is the objective function, $A$ is the constraint matrix, and $b$ is the constraint vector. Both $c$ and $A$ are linear functions.

The linear programming problem can be solved using various optimization algorithms, such as the simplex method, the dual simplex method, and the branch and cut method. These algorithms provide a way to find the optimal solution, which is the point that minimizes the objective function while satisfying all the constraints.

#### Applications of Linear Program

Linear programming has many applications in various fields. In finance, it is used to construct optimal portfolios, to price options, and to manage risk. In engineering, it is used to design optimal structures, to schedule production, and to allocate resources. In operations research, it is used to solve transportation problems, to schedule jobs, and to assign tasks to workers.

One of the most notable applications of linear programming is in the field of combinatorial optimization. Combinatorial optimization problems are a class of optimization problems where the decision variables can only take on a finite number of values. Many combinatorial optimization problems can be formulated as linear programs, and can be solved using the techniques of linear programming.

### Subsection: 2.7 Semidefinite Program

Semidefinite programming (SDP) is a powerful optimization technique that extends linear programming by allowing for the optimization of linear functions subject to linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). It is a special case of convex optimization, where the objective function and constraints are all convex functions. SDP is widely used in various fields, including control theory, combinatorial optimization, and machine learning.

#### Introduction to Semidefinite Program

Semidefinite programming is a method used to solve optimization problems with linear objective functions and linear matrix inequalities as constraints. It is based on the concept of positive semidefinite matrices, which are matrices that have all eigenvalues non-negative. This property allows us to solve complex optimization problems by breaking them down into simpler semidefinite subproblems.

The semidefinite program is formulated as:

$$
\min_{X} c^Tx
$$

subject to:

$$
F(X) \preceq 0
$$

where $c$ is the objective function, $F(X)$ is the constraint matrix, and $\preceq$ denotes the positive semidefinite ordering. Both $c$ and $F(X)$ are linear functions.

The semidefinite program can be solved using various optimization algorithms, such as the interior-point method, the cutting-plane method, and the trust region method. These algorithms provide a way to find the optimal solution, which is the point that minimizes the objective function while satisfying all the constraints.

#### Applications of Semidefinite Program

Semidefinite programming has many applications in various fields. In control theory, it is used to design robust controllers, to analyze stability, and to optimize performance. In combinatorial optimization, it is used to solve problems with graphical structure, such as the maximum cut problem and the graph coloring problem. In machine learning, it is used to solve problems with high-dimensional data, such as principal component analysis and clustering.

### Subsection: 2.8 Nonlinear Programming

Nonlinear programming (NLP) is a powerful optimization technique that extends linear programming by allowing for the optimization of nonlinear objective functions and constraints. It is a special case of convex optimization, where the objective function and constraints are all convex functions. Nonlinear programming is widely used in various fields, including engineering design, economics, and machine learning.

#### Introduction to Nonlinear Programming

Nonlinear programming is a method used to solve optimization problems with nonlinear objective functions and constraints. It is based on the concept of convexity, which states that the sum of convex functions is convex. This property allows us to solve complex optimization problems by breaking them down into simpler convex subproblems.

The nonlinear programming problem is formulated as:

$$
\min_{x} f(x)
$$

subject to:

$$
g_i(x) \leq 0, \quad i = 1, ..., m
$$

where $f(x)$ is the objective function, $g_i(x)$ are the constraint functions, and $x$ is the vector of decision variables. Both $f(x)$ and $g_i(x)$ are nonlinear functions.

The nonlinear programming problem can be solved using various optimization algorithms, such as the gradient descent method, the Newton's method, and the interior-point method. These algorithms provide a way to find the optimal solution, which is the point that minimizes the objective function while satisfying all the constraints.

#### Applications of Nonlinear Programming

Nonlinear programming has many applications in various fields. In engineering design, it is used to optimize the design of complex systems, such as aircraft, automobiles, and electronic devices. In economics, it is used to solve portfolio optimization problems, to determine the optimal pricing strategy, and to analyze market equilibrium. In machine learning, it is used to train complex models, such as neural networks and decision trees.

### Section: 3.2 SOS Formulation

The Sum of Squares (SOS) formulation is a powerful tool for solving nonlinear optimization problems. It is a convex relaxation of nonlinear optimization problems, meaning that it provides a lower bound on the optimal solution of the original problem. In this section, we will explore the SOS formulation in more detail and discuss its applications in nonlinear optimization.

#### 3.2a Introduction to SOS Formulation

The SOS formulation is a mathematical technique used to solve nonlinear optimization problems. It is based on the concept of sum of squares, where the objective function and constraints are expressed as a sum of squares of polynomials. This formulation is particularly useful for solving nonlinear optimization problems because it allows us to find a feasible solution quickly and efficiently.

The SOS formulation is a convex relaxation of nonlinear optimization problems, meaning that it provides a lower bound on the optimal solution. This means that the optimal solution of the SOS formulation is always less than or equal to the optimal solution of the original problem. This property makes the SOS formulation a powerful tool for finding feasible solutions to nonlinear optimization problems.

One of the main advantages of the SOS formulation is its ability to handle nonlinear optimization problems. Nonlinear optimization problems are often difficult to solve using traditional methods, but the SOS formulation provides a systematic approach to finding feasible solutions. Additionally, the SOS formulation provides a lower bound on the optimal solution, which can be useful for finding a feasible solution quickly.

The SOS formulation is particularly useful for solving optimization problems with polynomial constraints. These types of problems are commonly encountered in engineering design, economics, and machine learning. By expressing the constraints as a sum of squares of polynomials, the SOS formulation allows us to find feasible solutions to these types of problems efficiently.

#### 3.2b Applications of SOS Formulation

The SOS formulation has a wide range of applications in nonlinear optimization. One of the most common applications is in engineering design, where it is used to optimize the design of complex systems. The SOS formulation allows engineers to find feasible solutions to nonlinear optimization problems, such as minimizing the cost of a system while meeting certain performance requirements.

In economics, the SOS formulation is used to solve portfolio optimization problems. These types of problems involve finding the optimal allocation of assets in a portfolio to maximize returns while minimizing risk. The SOS formulation allows economists to find feasible solutions to these types of problems efficiently.

In machine learning, the SOS formulation is used to solve nonlinear optimization problems in training models. By expressing the constraints as a sum of squares of polynomials, the SOS formulation allows machine learning engineers to find feasible solutions to these types of problems quickly.

#### 3.2c Limitations of SOS Formulation

While the SOS formulation is a powerful tool for solving nonlinear optimization problems, it does have some limitations. One limitation is that it may not always provide the optimal solution. In some cases, the optimal solution of the SOS formulation may be significantly different from the optimal solution of the original problem.

Additionally, the SOS formulation may not be suitable for all types of nonlinear optimization problems. Some types of problems may not be able to be expressed as a sum of squares of polynomials, making the SOS formulation inapplicable.

Despite these limitations, the SOS formulation remains a valuable tool for solving nonlinear optimization problems. Its ability to handle nonlinear constraints and provide a lower bound on the optimal solution make it a popular choice for many types of optimization problems. 





### Section: 3.3 SOS Decomposition

The SOS decomposition is a powerful technique used in nonlinear optimization to decompose a nonlinear optimization problem into smaller, more manageable subproblems. This allows us to solve complex optimization problems by breaking them down into simpler subproblems, making it easier to find feasible solutions.

#### 3.3a Introduction to SOS Decomposition

The SOS decomposition is a method for solving nonlinear optimization problems by decomposing them into smaller, more manageable subproblems. This technique is particularly useful for solving optimization problems with a large number of variables and constraints. By breaking down the problem into smaller subproblems, we can find feasible solutions more efficiently and effectively.

The SOS decomposition is based on the concept of sum of squares (SOS) formulation, which is a convex relaxation of nonlinear optimization problems. The SOS formulation allows us to express the objective function and constraints as a sum of squares of polynomials, making it easier to find feasible solutions. The SOS decomposition is particularly useful for solving optimization problems with a large number of variables and constraints. #### 3.3b Properties of SOS Decomposition

### Section: 3.4 SOS Hierarchy

The SOS hierarchy is a powerful tool for solving nonlinear optimization problems. It is an extension of the SOS decomposition and allows us to systematically solve more complex optimization problems. In this section, we will introduce the concept of the SOS hierarchy and discuss its applications in nonlinear optimization.

#### 3.4a Introduction to SOS Hierarchy

The SOS hierarchy is a method for solving nonlinear optimization problems by decomposing them into smaller, more manageable subproblems. It is an extension of the SOS decomposition and allows us to solve more complex optimization problems. The SOS hierarchy is particularly useful for solving optimization problems with a large number of variables and constraints.

The SOS hierarchy is based on the concept of sum of squares (SOS) formulation, which is a convex relaxation of nonlinear optimization problems. The SOS formulation allows us to express the objective function and constraints as a sum of squares of polynomials, making it easier to find feasible solutions. By decomposing the problem into smaller subproblems, we can apply the SOS formulation to each subproblem and then combine the solutions to find a feasible solution to the original problem.

The SOS hierarchy is particularly useful for solving optimization problems with a large number of variables and constraints. By breaking down the problem into smaller subproblems, we can reduce the complexity of the problem and make it easier to solve. This is especially important in real-world applications where the number of variables and constraints can be in the thousands or even millions.

One of the main advantages of the SOS hierarchy is its ability to handle nonlinear optimization problems. Nonlinear optimization problems are often difficult to solve using traditional methods, but the SOS hierarchy provides a systematic approach to finding feasible solutions. Additionally, the SOS hierarchy allows us to systematically improve the solution by solving smaller subproblems and then combining the solutions to find a better overall solution.

#### 3.4b Applications of SOS Hierarchy

The SOS hierarchy has a wide range of applications in nonlinear optimization. It is particularly useful for solving optimization problems with a large number of variables and constraints. Some common applications of the SOS hierarchy include:

- Portfolio optimization: The SOS hierarchy can be used to solve portfolio optimization problems, where the goal is to find the optimal allocation of assets to maximize returns while minimizing risk.
- Robust optimization: The SOS hierarchy can be used to solve robust optimization problems, where the goal is to find a solution that is robust to variations in the problem data.
- Nonlinear control: The SOS hierarchy can be used to solve nonlinear control problems, where the goal is to find a control policy that optimizes a nonlinear objective function while satisfying constraints.
- Combinatorial optimization: The SOS hierarchy can be used to solve combinatorial optimization problems, where the goal is to find the optimal solution from a finite set of possible solutions.

#### 3.4c Challenges in SOS Hierarchy

While the SOS hierarchy is a powerful tool for solving nonlinear optimization problems, it also has some challenges that must be addressed. One of the main challenges is the computational complexity of solving the SOS hierarchy. As the number of variables and constraints increases, the complexity of the problem also increases, making it difficult to find a feasible solution in a reasonable amount of time.

Another challenge is the sensitivity of the SOS hierarchy to changes in the problem data. Small changes in the problem data can lead to significant changes in the solution, making it difficult to find a robust solution.

Despite these challenges, the SOS hierarchy remains a valuable tool for solving nonlinear optimization problems. With advancements in computational methods and techniques, these challenges can be addressed to make the SOS hierarchy even more powerful and useful in solving real-world problems.





### Subsection: 3.5a Introduction to SOS Relaxations

In the previous section, we discussed the SOS hierarchy and its applications in nonlinear optimization. In this section, we will introduce the concept of SOS relaxations, which is a powerful tool for solving nonlinear optimization problems.

SOS relaxations are a type of relaxation of nonlinear optimization problems, similar to the SOS decomposition and hierarchy. They allow us to systematically solve more complex optimization problems by decomposing them into smaller, more manageable subproblems. However, unlike the SOS decomposition and hierarchy, SOS relaxations do not require the objective function and constraints to be expressed as a sum of squares of polynomials.

The concept of SOS relaxations was first introduced by Nesterov and Nemirovskii in the 1960s. It has since been widely used in various fields, including optimization, control theory, and combinatorial optimization. SOS relaxations have proven to be a powerful tool for solving nonlinear optimization problems, particularly in cases where the objective function and constraints are non-convex.

The main idea behind SOS relaxations is to relax the constraints of a nonlinear optimization problem while still maintaining the feasibility of the solution. This is achieved by introducing additional variables and constraints, which allow us to express the original problem as a convex optimization problem. The solution to the relaxed problem then provides a lower bound on the optimal solution of the original problem.

One of the key advantages of SOS relaxations is their ability to handle non-convex optimization problems. Non-convex optimization problems are often difficult to solve using traditional methods, but SOS relaxations provide a systematic approach to finding feasible solutions. Additionally, SOS relaxations allow us to systematically improve the lower bound on the optimal solution, leading to more efficient solutions.

In the next section, we will discuss the different types of SOS relaxations and their applications in nonlinear optimization. We will also provide examples and case studies to illustrate the effectiveness of SOS relaxations in solving real-world problems.

## Chapter 4: Measure and Moments for Nonlinear Optimization:




### Section: 4.2 Moment Matrices

In the previous section, we discussed the concept of moments and their importance in nonlinear optimization. In this section, we will delve deeper into the concept of moment matrices and their role in nonlinear optimization.

#### 4.2a Introduction to Moment Matrices

Moment matrices are a crucial tool in nonlinear optimization, providing a way to capture the higher-order moments of a nonlinear function. They are particularly useful in the context of nonlinear optimization, where the function may not be easily represented using a Taylor series expansion.

The moment matrix, denoted as $M$, is a matrix that contains the moments of a function. The $(i,j)$th element of the moment matrix, $M_{ij}$, represents the $i$th moment of the $j$th variable. In other words, $M_{ij}$ is the $i$th derivative of the $j$th variable with respect to the input variables.

The moment matrix is a powerful tool in nonlinear optimization as it allows us to capture the nonlinear behavior of a function. By using the moment matrix, we can approximate the nonlinear function using a Taylor series expansion, which can then be used to find the optimal solution.

In the next section, we will discuss the properties of moment matrices and how they can be used in nonlinear optimization.

#### 4.2b Properties of Moment Matrices

Moment matrices have several important properties that make them useful in nonlinear optimization. These properties are:

1. Symmetry: The moment matrix is a symmetric matrix, meaning that $M_{ij} = M_{ji}$. This property is useful in simplifying the optimization problem.

2. Positive definiteness: The moment matrix is a positive definite matrix, meaning that all of its eigenvalues are positive. This property is important in ensuring the convergence of optimization algorithms.

3. Rank: The rank of the moment matrix is equal to the number of input variables. This property is useful in determining the number of variables that need to be optimized.

4. Invertibility: The moment matrix is invertible, meaning that it has a unique inverse. This property is important in solving optimization problems.

5. Sensitivity to changes in input variables: The moment matrix is sensitive to changes in the input variables, meaning that small changes in the input variables can result in significant changes in the moment matrix. This property is useful in capturing the nonlinear behavior of a function.

In the next section, we will discuss how moment matrices can be used in nonlinear optimization.

#### 4.2c Applications of Moment Matrices

Moment matrices have a wide range of applications in nonlinear optimization. Some of the most common applications include:

1. Approximating nonlinear functions: As mentioned earlier, moment matrices can be used to approximate nonlinear functions using a Taylor series expansion. This is particularly useful in cases where the nonlinear function is complex and difficult to represent using traditional methods.

2. Solving optimization problems: The properties of moment matrices, such as symmetry, positive definiteness, and invertibility, make them useful in solving optimization problems. They can be used to formulate the optimization problem and find the optimal solution.

3. Sensitivity analysis: The sensitivity of moment matrices to changes in input variables makes them useful in conducting sensitivity analysis. By varying the input variables, we can observe how the moment matrix changes, providing insights into the nonlinear behavior of the function.

4. Nonlinear system identification: Moment matrices can also be used in nonlinear system identification, where they are used to identify the parameters of a nonlinear system. This is particularly useful in cases where the system is complex and difficult to model using traditional methods.

In the next section, we will discuss some examples of how moment matrices can be used in nonlinear optimization.

#### 4.2d Examples of Moment Matrices

To further illustrate the concept of moment matrices, let's consider a simple example. Suppose we have a nonlinear function $f(x,y) = x^2 + y^2 + xy$. The moment matrix for this function can be calculated as follows:

$$
M = \begin{bmatrix}
2 & 1 \\
1 & 2
\end{bmatrix}
$$

We can see that the moment matrix is a symmetric matrix, with all eigenvalues being positive. This satisfies the properties of moment matrices discussed earlier.

Using the moment matrix, we can approximate the nonlinear function using a Taylor series expansion. This can be useful in cases where the nonlinear function is complex and difficult to represent using traditional methods.

In conclusion, moment matrices are a powerful tool in nonlinear optimization, providing a way to capture the higher-order moments of a nonlinear function. They have several important properties that make them useful in solving optimization problems and understanding the nonlinear behavior of functions. In the next section, we will discuss some advanced concepts in nonlinear optimization, including the use of moment matrices.


## Chapter 4: Measure and Moments for Nonlinear Optimization:




#### 4.3a Introduction to Moment Relaxations

In the previous sections, we have discussed the concept of moments and moment matrices in the context of nonlinear optimization. In this section, we will introduce the concept of moment relaxations, which is a powerful tool for solving nonlinear optimization problems.

Moment relaxations are a way of approximating the nonlinear optimization problem with a linear one, making it easier to solve. This is achieved by relaxing the constraints on the nonlinear optimization problem, resulting in a linear optimization problem. The solution to the linear optimization problem then serves as an approximation to the solution of the original nonlinear optimization problem.

The concept of moment relaxations is closely related to the concept of moment matrices. In fact, the moment matrix plays a crucial role in the formulation of moment relaxations. The moment matrix is used to capture the nonlinear behavior of the function, and by relaxing the constraints on the moment matrix, we can transform the nonlinear optimization problem into a linear one.

In the next subsection, we will discuss the properties of moment relaxations and how they can be used in nonlinear optimization.

#### 4.3b Properties of Moment Relaxations

Moment relaxations have several important properties that make them useful in nonlinear optimization. These properties are:

1. Approximation: Moment relaxations provide an approximation to the solution of the original nonlinear optimization problem. This approximation can be as accurate as desired by choosing a sufficiently large moment matrix.

2. Linearity: The moment relaxation is a linear optimization problem, making it easier to solve compared to the original nonlinear optimization problem. This is because linear optimization problems can be solved efficiently using well-established algorithms.

3. Robustness: Moment relaxations are robust to small perturbations in the moment matrix. This means that even if the moment matrix is slightly perturbed, the solution to the moment relaxation will not be significantly affected.

4. Convergence: The solution to the moment relaxation converges to the solution of the original nonlinear optimization problem as the moment matrix becomes larger. This property ensures that the approximation provided by the moment relaxation becomes more accurate as we include more moments in the relaxation.

In the next section, we will discuss how to formulate moment relaxations and how to solve them efficiently.

#### 4.3c Applications of Moment Relaxations

Moment relaxations have a wide range of applications in nonlinear optimization. They are particularly useful in situations where the nonlinear optimization problem is difficult to solve due to its complexity or the presence of constraints. In this section, we will discuss some of the key applications of moment relaxations.

1. Nonlinear Least Squares: Moment relaxations can be used to solve nonlinear least squares problems. These are problems where the goal is to minimize the sum of the squares of the differences between the predicted and actual values. Moment relaxations provide an efficient way to approximate the solution to these problems.

2. Nonlinear Constraint Satisfaction: Moment relaxations can be used to solve nonlinear constraint satisfaction problems. These are problems where the goal is to find a solution that satisfies a set of nonlinear constraints. Moment relaxations provide a way to approximate the solution to these problems by relaxing the constraints.

3. Nonlinear Programming: Moment relaxations can be used to solve nonlinear programming problems. These are problems where the goal is to optimize a nonlinear objective function subject to a set of nonlinear constraints. Moment relaxations provide an efficient way to approximate the solution to these problems.

4. Nonlinear Control: Moment relaxations can be used in nonlinear control problems. These are problems where the goal is to control a system with nonlinear dynamics. Moment relaxations provide a way to approximate the control law that minimizes the error between the desired and actual system states.

In the next section, we will discuss how to formulate moment relaxations and how to solve them efficiently.

### Subsection: 5.2 Moment-Based SDPs

In the previous section, we discussed the duality of SOS and Moment-Based SDPs. We saw that these two techniques are essentially the same thing, but viewed from different perspectives. In this section, we will delve deeper into the Moment-Based SDPs and explore their properties and applications.

#### 5.2a Introduction to Moment-Based SDPs

The Moment-Based Semidefinite Programming (SDP) is a powerful tool for solving nonlinear optimization problems. It is based on the concept of representing a nonlinear function as a sum of squares of polynomials, similar to the SOS. However, unlike the SOS, the Moment-Based SDPs provide a method for solving these optimization problems.

The Moment-Based SDPs are based on the concept of moments, which are defined as the integrals of increasing powers of a variable. For example, the first moment of a function $f(x)$ is given by $\mu_1 = \int x f(x) dx$, the second moment is given by $\mu_2 = \int x^2 f(x) dx$, and so on.

The Moment-Based SDPs use these moments to construct a semidefinite program, which is a type of optimization problem where the decision variables are positive semidefinite matrices. The goal of the Moment-Based SDPs is to find the optimal solution to this semidefinite program, which represents the optimal value of the original nonlinear optimization problem.

The Moment-Based SDPs have been successfully applied to a wide range of problems, including polynomial optimization, semidefinite relaxations of combinatorial optimization problems, and robust optimization. They have also been used in the development of new algorithms for solving nonlinear optimization problems.

In the next section, we will explore the properties of the Moment-Based SDPs and discuss how they can be used to solve complex optimization problems. We will also provide examples and case studies to illustrate the practical applications of these properties.

#### 5.2b Properties of Moment-Based SDPs

The Moment-Based SDPs have several important properties that make them a powerful tool for solving nonlinear optimization problems. These properties include:

1. **Convexity:** The Moment-Based SDPs are convex optimization problems. This means that any local minimum of the problem is also a global minimum. This property is crucial for the efficiency of optimization algorithms, as it allows us to find the optimal solution in a finite number of steps.

2. **Semidefinite Relaxation:** The Moment-Based SDPs provide a semidefinite relaxation of the original nonlinear optimization problem. This means that the solution to the Moment-Based SDP is always a lower bound on the optimal solution of the original problem. This property is useful for obtaining good initial guesses for the solution of the original problem.

3. **Robustness:** The Moment-Based SDPs are robust to small perturbations in the data. This means that even if the data used to construct the problem is slightly corrupted, the solution of the Moment-Based SDP will not be significantly affected. This property is particularly useful in real-world applications, where the data is often noisy.

4. **Dual Feasibility:** The dual of the Moment-Based SDP is always feasible. This means that there always exists a feasible solution to the dual problem. This property is useful for proving the optimality of the solution of the Moment-Based SDP.

5. **Strong Duality:** Under certain conditions, the dual of the Moment-Based SDP is also a convex optimization problem. In this case, the strong duality theorem guarantees that the optimal solutions of the primal and dual problems coincide. This property is useful for obtaining a certificate of optimality for the solution of the Moment-Based SDP.

In the next section, we will explore how these properties can be used to solve complex optimization problems. We will also provide examples and case studies to illustrate the practical applications of these properties.

#### 5.2c Applications of Moment-Based SDPs

The Moment-Based SDPs have been applied to a wide range of problems since their introduction. In this section, we will discuss some of the key applications of these techniques.

1. **Polynomial Optimization:** The Moment-Based SDPs have been used to solve polynomial optimization problems. These are optimization problems where the decision variables and the objective function are polynomials. The Moment-Based SDPs provide a semidefinite relaxation of these problems, which can be solved efficiently using standard optimization algorithms. This approach has been applied to a variety of problems, including the optimization of multivariate polynomials and the optimization of polynomials subject to constraints.

2. **Semidefinite Relaxations of Combinatorial Optimization Problems:** The Moment-Based SDPs have been used to construct semidefinite relaxations of a variety of combinatorial optimization problems. These include the maximum cut problem, the graph coloring problem, and the knapsack problem. The Moment-Based SDPs provide a way to solve these problems efficiently, even when they are NP-hard.

3. **Robust Optimization:** The robustness of the Moment-Based SDPs makes them particularly useful for robust optimization problems. These are optimization problems where the goal is to find a solution that is optimal for a worst-case scenario. The Moment-Based SDPs provide a way to solve these problems efficiently, even when the worst-case scenario is not known in advance.

4. **Duality Gap Analysis:** The strong duality property of the Moment-Based SDPs can be used for duality gap analysis. This is a technique for analyzing the optimality of the solution of an optimization problem. By comparing the primal and dual solutions, one can gain insights into the structure of the problem and the quality of the solution.

The following theorem is of fundamental importance to duality theory because it completely characterizes the continuous dual space of <math>(X, \sigma(X, Y, b)).</math>

Consequently, the continuous dual space of <math>(X, \sigma(X, Y, b))</math> is

### Conclusion

In this chapter, we have explored the duality of SOS and moment-based semidefinite programming (SDPs). We have seen how these two approaches are closely related and how they can be used to solve nonlinear optimization problems. By understanding the duality between SOS and moment-based SDPs, we can gain a deeper understanding of the underlying structure of nonlinear optimization problems and develop more efficient and effective solution methods.

We began by discussing the basics of SOS and moment-based SDPs, including their formulations and properties. We then delved into the duality between these two approaches, exploring how they can be used to solve the same nonlinear optimization problems. We saw that the duality between SOS and moment-based SDPs allows us to transform a problem in one form into a problem in the other form, providing us with a powerful tool for solving nonlinear optimization problems.

Furthermore, we discussed the advantages and limitations of using SOS and moment-based SDPs. We saw that while these approaches have many similarities, they also have some key differences that can impact their performance. By understanding these differences, we can make informed decisions about which approach is best suited for a given problem.

Overall, the duality of SOS and moment-based SDPs is a powerful concept that can greatly enhance our understanding and ability to solve nonlinear optimization problems. By incorporating this duality into our problem-solving strategies, we can develop more efficient and effective methods for tackling complex nonlinear problems.

### Exercises

#### Exercise 1
Prove the duality between SOS and moment-based SDPs by showing that the dual of an SOS problem is a moment-based SDP and vice versa.

#### Exercise 2
Consider the following nonlinear optimization problem:
$$
\begin{align*}
\text{minimize} \quad & c^Tx \\
\text{subject to} \quad & f(x) \leq 0
\end{align*}
$$
where $c \in \mathbb{R}^n$ and $f(x)$ is a nonlinear function. Show that this problem can be formulated as an SOS problem and a moment-based SDP.

#### Exercise 3
Discuss the advantages and limitations of using SOS and moment-based SDPs in solving nonlinear optimization problems. Provide examples to support your discussion.

#### Exercise 4
Consider the following nonlinear optimization problem:
$$
\begin{align*}
\text{minimize} \quad & c^Tx \\
\text{subject to} \quad & f(x) \leq 0 \\
& g(x) = 0
\end{align*}
$$
where $c \in \mathbb{R}^n$, $f(x)$ is a nonlinear function, and $g(x)$ is a linear function. Show that this problem can be formulated as an SOS problem and a moment-based SDP.

#### Exercise 5
Discuss the implications of the duality between SOS and moment-based SDPs for the development of efficient and effective solution methods for nonlinear optimization problems. Provide examples to support your discussion.

### Subsection: 6.2a Introduction to Modified SOS Relaxations

In the previous chapters, we have explored the fundamentals of risk aware and robust nonlinear planning, and have introduced the concept of sum-of-squares relaxations. We have seen how the sum-of-squares relaxation can be used to transform a nonlinear optimization problem into a semidefinite program, which can be solved efficiently using existing solvers. However, the sum-of-squares relaxation is not always tight, meaning that the solution obtained from the relaxation may not be the optimal solution of the original problem.

In this section, we will delve deeper into the topic and discuss modified sum-of-squares relaxations for large-scale optimizations. These modifications aim to improve the tightness of the relaxation, making it more effective for solving real-world problems.

#### 6.2a.1 Modified SOS Relaxations

Modified sum-of-squares relaxations are a set of techniques that can be used to improve the tightness of the sum-of-squares relaxation. These techniques are particularly useful for large-scale optimizations, where the number of variables and constraints can make the problem difficult to solve.

One of the main modifications to the sum-of-squares relaxation is the introduction of additional variables and constraints. These additional variables and constraints are used to augment the basic convex program at the first level of the hierarchy to the d-th level. This allows the program to consider polynomials of degree at most 2d, which can improve the tightness of the relaxation.

Another modification is the use of duality. The dual of the sum-of-squares relaxation provides a way to bound the objective value using polynomials of degree at most 2d. This can be used to prove guarantees on the tightness of the relaxation.

#### 6.2a.2 Applications of Modified SOS Relaxations

Modified sum-of-squares relaxations have been successfully applied to a variety of problems, including polynomial optimization, semidefinite programming, and combinatorial optimization. These modifications have been shown to improve the performance of the sum-of-squares relaxation, making it a powerful tool for solving large-scale nonlinear optimization problems.

In the next section, we will explore some of these applications in more detail and discuss how the modified sum-of-squares relaxations can be applied to solve real-world problems.





### Subsection: 6.3a Introduction to SDP Hierarchies

In the previous sections, we have discussed the concept of sum-of-squares relaxations and their modifications for large-scale optimizations. In this section, we will introduce another powerful tool for solving large-scale optimizations: the semidefinite programming (SDP) hierarchy.

The SDP hierarchy is a method for solving semidefinite programs (SDPs) that are too large to be solved directly. It is based on the idea of hierarchical decomposition, where the original problem is decomposed into smaller subproblems that can be solved more efficiently. The solutions of these subproblems are then combined to form a solution to the original problem.

#### 6.3a.1 The SDP Hierarchy

The SDP hierarchy is a sequence of SDPs that are increasingly more complex. The first level of the hierarchy is the basic convex program, which is the original SDP. The subsequent levels introduce additional variables and constraints, similar to the modified sum-of-squares relaxations.

The SDP hierarchy provides a way to systematically solve larger and larger versions of the original problem. The solutions of the lower levels of the hierarchy can be used to provide bounds on the optimal solution of the original problem. This allows us to systematically improve the solution of the original problem, while ensuring that the solution remains feasible.

#### 6.3a.2 Applications of SDP Hierarchies

SDP hierarchies have been successfully applied to a variety of problems, including polynomial optimization, combinatorial optimization, and machine learning. They provide a powerful tool for solving large-scale optimizations that are too complex to be solved directly.

In the next section, we will delve deeper into the concept of SDP hierarchies and discuss how they can be used to solve large-scale optimizations. We will also discuss some of the challenges and limitations of using SDP hierarchies.

### Section: 7.1 Chance-Constrained Optimization:

Chance-constrained optimization is a powerful tool that allows us to handle nonlinear constraints and uncertainties in our planning and optimization problems. It provides a framework for decision-making under uncertainty, where the goal is to find a solution that satisfies the constraints with a certain probability. This approach is particularly useful in situations where the constraints are nonlinear and the uncertainties are non-Gaussian.

#### 7.1a Introduction to Chance-Constrained Optimization

Chance-constrained optimization is a mathematical optimization technique that is used to solve problems where the constraints are not deterministic but probabilistic. In other words, the constraints are not fixed but vary randomly within a certain range. This is often the case in real-world problems where there are uncertainties and random variations in the system.

The goal of chance-constrained optimization is to find a solution that satisfies the constraints with a certain probability. This is achieved by formulating the problem as a chance-constrained optimization problem, where the constraints are expressed as probabilistic constraints. The solution to this problem is then a set of decisions that satisfy the probabilistic constraints with a certain probability.

The probabilistic constraints in chance-constrained optimization can be of two types: chance constraints and robust constraints. Chance constraints are constraints that must be satisfied with a certain probability, while robust constraints are constraints that must be satisfied for all possible values of the uncertain parameters.

The formulation of a chance-constrained optimization problem can be written as follows:

$$
\begin{align*}
\min_{x} \quad & f(x) \\
\text{s.t.} \quad & P(g_i(x) \leq 0) \geq \alpha_i, \quad i = 1, \ldots, m \\
& h_j(x) = 0, \quad j = 1, \ldots, p
\end{align*}
$$

where $x$ is the decision variable, $f(x)$ is the objective function, $g_i(x)$ are the chance constraints, $h_j(x)$ are the robust constraints, and $\alpha_i$ are the probability levels.

In the next sections, we will delve deeper into the theory and applications of chance-constrained optimization, including sensitivity analysis and algorithmic considerations. We will also provide numerous examples and case studies to illustrate the practical applications of this method.

1. **Robustness:** Chance-constrained optimization is a robust optimization technique. This means that it provides solutions that are robust to variations in the uncertain parameters. In other words, the solutions obtained from chance-constrained optimization are not overly sensitive to small changes in the uncertain parameters. This property is particularly useful in real-world problems where the uncertain parameters can vary randomly.

2. **Probabilistic Constraints:** The probabilistic constraints in chance-constrained optimization allow for a more realistic representation of the constraints in many real-world problems. This is because the constraints are often not deterministic but probabilistic. By formulating the problem as a chance-constrained optimization problem, we can capture this probabilistic nature of the constraints.

3. **Flexibility:** Chance-constrained optimization is a flexible optimization technique. This means that it can handle a wide range of problems, including problems with nonlinear constraints and non-Gaussian uncertainties. This flexibility makes it a valuable tool for solving a variety of real-world problems.

4. **Probabilistic Guarantees:** The solutions obtained from chance-constrained optimization come with probabilistic guarantees. This means that we can be confident that the solutions satisfy the constraints with a certain probability. This is particularly useful in decision-making under uncertainty, where we need to make decisions that are robust to variations in the uncertain parameters.

5. **Algorithmic Efficiency:** Chance-constrained optimization can be solved efficiently using a variety of optimization algorithms. This includes both deterministic and stochastic optimization algorithms. This makes it a practical technique for solving real-world problems.

#### 7.2b Techniques for Chance Optimization

In this section, we will discuss some of the techniques used in chance optimization. These techniques are designed to handle the uncertainties and random variations in the system, and to find a solution that maximizes the expected value of the objective function.

##### Random Search

Random search is a simple but powerful technique for chance optimization. It involves generating random solutions and evaluating them according to the objective function. The best solutions are then selected and used to generate the next round of random solutions. This process continues until a satisfactory solution is found.

Random search is particularly useful in situations where the objective function is nonlinear and the constraints are probabilistic. It allows for a comprehensive exploration of the solution space, and can often find solutions that other methods might miss.

##### Genetic Algorithms

Genetic algorithms are a type of evolutionary algorithm that is often used in chance optimization. They are inspired by the process of natural selection and evolution, and involve generating a population of solutions and then using genetic operators such as mutation and crossover to evolve the population over time.

Genetic algorithms are particularly useful in situations where the objective function is nonlinear and the constraints are probabilistic. They allow for a systematic exploration of the solution space, and can often find solutions that other methods might miss.

##### Simulated Annealing

Simulated annealing is a probabilistic technique for chance optimization. It is inspired by the process of annealing in metallurgy, and involves generating a sequence of solutions by making small changes to the current solution. The changes are accepted if they improve the objective function, and are accepted with a certain probability if they worsen the objective function.

Simulated annealing is particularly useful in situations where the objective function is nonlinear and the constraints are probabilistic. It allows for a systematic exploration of the solution space, and can often find solutions that other methods might miss.

##### Particle Swarm Optimization

Particle swarm optimization is a population-based optimization technique that is often used in chance optimization. It is inspired by the behavior of bird flocks and fish schools, and involves a population of solutions (particles) moving through the solution space. The particles are attracted to the best solutions found so far, and repelled from the worst solutions.

Particle swarm optimization is particularly useful in situations where the objective function is nonlinear and the constraints are probabilistic. It allows for a comprehensive exploration of the solution space, and can often find solutions that other methods might miss.

#### 7.2b Chance Optimization Algorithms

There are several algorithms that can be used to solve chance optimization problems. These include the sample average approximation (SAA) algorithm, the scenario-based optimization (SBO) algorithm, and the robust optimization (RO) algorithm.

The SAA algorithm is a Monte Carlo-based method that approximates the expected value of the objective function by taking a large number of samples from the probability distribution of the uncertain parameters. The solution to the SAA algorithm is then a set of decisions that maximize the sample average of the objective function.

The SBO algorithm is a deterministic global optimization method that is used to solve chance optimization problems. It involves solving a finite number of deterministic optimization problems, where each problem is formulated using a different scenario of the uncertain parameters. The solution to the SBO algorithm is then a set of decisions that maximize the worst-case value of the objective function over all scenarios.

The RO algorithm is a robust optimization method that is used to solve chance optimization problems. It involves solving a deterministic optimization problem that is formulated using a robust optimization formulation, where the uncertain parameters are represented by a set of uncertainty sets. The solution to the RO algorithm is then a set of decisions that maximize the worst-case value of the objective function over all uncertainty sets.
